passages.title: Passage I
passages.text:
Returning home after a decade and half abroad, our Geography master remained incurably addicted to foreign ways and ideas for years after landing here. He would forever stick to his theory of Africans suffering from a curse inflicted on them by the Almighty God for some heinous sins committed centuries ago. He would, in support of this theory, ask listeners:

"Why would our mosquito inflict deadly malaria on us whereas the British mosquito does not bite? Why aren't there poisonous snakes in Britain whereas here most snakes are deadly?

Why should the deadly sickle cell disease be peculiar to the black race?"

Of course, he hardly waits for answers to these and similar questions before jumping to the same inevitable conclusion. However, he met his match one day when a new student joined the class and heard the litany we were used to. The new boy calmly said, "Sir, I happen to know a few white men who suffer from the sickle cell disease; some are Italians and some are Spanish. The mosquito is equally deadly in India, South-east Asian countries and South America. The United States and some other South American countries have their deadly snakes. And, Sir, I know many white men, some of them British, who would prefer our brilliant sunshine to their horribly cold winter." And he sat down.

I had never, before that day, seen our master so consumed with anger. He directed a burning look at the poor boy, who had no answer to this new battle. Without as much as saying a single word, the master stalked out of the classroom. Needless to say, our anger was turned on the new boy, who had decided to rock the boat without taking the time to sound the water. A delegation was sent to the master to apologise to him.

He was appeased. But we all noticed something rather unusual thereafter: never again did he dwell on the issue of Africans being the cursed people.

passages.title: Passage II
passages.text:
Mankind has been ravaged by many virus and ...7... diseases such as measles, tuberculosis, diarrhoea and many others including ...8... known also as the ...9... cold.

Outbreaks of many of these diseases have been brought under control in the last fifty years. Some ...10... like measles and whooping cough still pose a great danger to younger children.

The ...11... of measles are more easily ...12... than those of whooping cough. Unlike that of many others, the virus of measles more easily remain ...13... for hundreds of years. However, once you have had an ...14... of this dreadful disease, you develop an ...15... which is almost complete and long lasting. Modern science has made available ...16... to prevent many childhood diseases and this is the only guarantee of ...17... from these scourges. More effective treatment of complications arising from these childhood diseases using penicillin and other ...18... has also helped to reduce the ...19... rate among children.

It is universally accepted that good ...20... is the right of every human being and children. You do not have to die from these diseases which wiped out the whole ...21... in the middle ages. We have today ...22... drugs which give protection against most childhood diseases.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 6, read Passage I and answer the questions that follow.
In questions 7 to 22, Passage II has gaps. For each numbered gap, choose from the options the word that best completes the gap.
In each of questions 23 to 33, a sentence is followed by a list of possible interpretations. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for the sentence.
In each of questions 34 to 43, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 44 to 50, choose the option that best completes the gap(s).
In each of questions 51 to 55, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 56 to 57, choose the option that has the same sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.
In each of questions 58 to 60, choose the option that has the correct stress pattern. The stressed syllable(s) are written in capital letters.

questions.question: What point of view is the Geography master fond of advancing?

options.text: Africans are infested with all kinds of problem.
Only the white men are free from deadly diseases.
The Almighty God is punishing Africans for sins they committed long ago.
God did not curse the white people.

questions.explanation: The passage tells us that the master "would forever stick to his theory of Africans suffering from a curse inflicted on them by the Almighty God for some heinous sins committed centuries ago." That is exactly the idea in option C. Options A and B are details he uses, but his central thesis is that a divine curse explains African problems.

questions.question: Which of the following arguments did he not use to support his views?

options.text: In Africa, the mosquito causes deadly malaria whereas in Britain, it doesn't bite or cause malaria.
There is malaria both in Britain and in African countries.
The snakes in Africa are deadly but those in Britain are harmless.
The sickle cell disease is peculiar to the black race.

questions.explanation: The master asks, "Why would our mosquito inflict deadly malaria on us whereas the British mosquito does not bite?" and "Why aren't there poisonous snakes in Britain whereas here most snakes are deadly?" He also claims sickle‑cell disease is peculiar to the black race. So A, C and D echo his claims. He never says malaria occurs in both Africa and Britain; that is actually the opposite of his point. Hence B is the argument he **did not** use.

questions.question: "...rock the boat". What figure of speech is this expression?
questions.explanation: The narrator says the new boy "decided to rock the boat", meaning he disturbed a settled situation by challenging the master's views. No actual boat is involved; the class situation is compared *implicitly* to a boat without using "like" or "as". This is a metaphor. A simile would require 'like/as', personification gives human qualities to non‑humans, and hyperbole exaggerates for effect.

questions.question: What extra argument did the new boy offer after countering each of the master's points?

options.text: There are problems especially in Africa.
There are deadly snakes in America and Africa.
There are harmless snakes in Britain.
Many white men prefer the African climate to their own.

questions.explanation: The new boy first counters each claim: white people can get sickle cell, mosquitoes are deadly in other regions, and many countries have deadly snakes. Then he adds, "And, Sir, I know many white men, some of them British, who would prefer our brilliant sunshine to their horribly cold winter." This extra argument (D) undermines the master's belief that Africa is uniquely cursed and undesirable.

questions.question: Why do you think the master fought back with his look rather than with further argument?

options.text: He knew that the boy's points were valid.
He had answers to the boy's argument.
He went out to sort for the boy's argument.
He had already made up his mind on his points.

questions.explanation: The master, "consumed with anger", fixes the boy with a "burning look" and stalks out of the room without speaking. This behaviour suggests that he cannot refute the boy logically and is reacting emotionally instead. That implies he recognises the strength of the boy's arguments (A). D is partly true—he is dogmatic—but the specific reason for the silent anger is that the new arguments have effectively challenged him.

questions.question: "...who had no answer to this new battle." What grammatical name is given to this expression as it is used in the passage?
questions.explanation: The phrase "who had no answer to this new battle" begins with the relative pronoun *who* and gives extra information about "the poor boy". It is not essential for the basic structure of the sentence and is set off by commas in standard punctuation. That makes it a non‑defining (non‑restrictive) relative clause. All relative clauses are subordinate, but the question asks for the specific grammatical name, which is option A.

questions.question: Mankind has been ravaged by many virus and ....7.... diseases such as measles, tuberculosis, diarrhoea and many others including ....8.... known also as the ....9.... cold.
questions.explanation: We normally speak of "viral and bacterial diseases". Here "many virus" (viruses) are one category; the other category of diseases should be 'bacterial'. 'Germ' is a general word, and 'dirty' or 'mosquito' do not classify types of diseases.

questions.question: Mankind has been ravaged by many virus and ....7.... diseases such as measles, tuberculosis, diarrhoea and many others including ....8.... known also as the ....9.... cold.
questions.explanation: The passage later refers to the "... cold". The everyday name for a mild nasal and throat infection—the common cold—is also 'catarrh'. 'Runny‑nose' is a symptom, not the disease name; 'influenza' is flu, a more serious viral infection.

questions.question: Mankind has been ravaged by many virus and ....7.... diseases such as measles, tuberculosis, diarrhoea and many others including catarrh known also as the ....9.... cold.
questions.explanation: The fixed expression in English is "the **common** cold". 'Sporadic' and 'regular' relate to frequency, and 'universal' suggests everywhere, but none of these collocate with 'cold' in the medical term.

questions.question: Outbreaks of many of these diseases have been brought under control in the last fifty years. Some ....10.... like measles and whooping cough still pose a great danger to younger children.
questions.explanation: Measles and whooping cough are specific **infections**, i.e. infectious diseases. 'Pains' and 'fevers' are symptoms, not the diseases themselves, and 'traces' does not fit the medical context.

questions.question: The ....11.... of measles are more easily ....12.... than those of whooping cough.
questions.explanation: Measles and whooping cough present with particular **symptoms** (rash, cough, etc.). Doctors diagnose diseases based on their symptoms. 'Signs' is close, but 'symptoms' is the more precise medical term used with 'diagnose'.

questions.question: The symptoms of measles are more easily ....12.... than those of whooping cough.
questions.explanation: Symptoms are things that are **diagnosed** (identified) by doctors; they are then treated afterwards. Option A therefore fits the verb–object relationship. B, C and D describe what you do *after* diagnosis.

questions.question: Unlike that of many others, the virus of measles more easily remain ....13.... for hundreds of years.
questions.explanation: The statement is about how the measles virus behaves over long periods. It says it can remain in the same state for centuries. The best word for that is "unchanged". 'Constant' is close in meaning but less natural here; 'undiscovered' speaks about our knowledge, not the virus itself, and 'erratic' means irregular—the opposite of the idea.

questions.question: However, once you have had an ....14.... of this dreadful disease, you develop an ....15....
questions.explanation: In medical English we say "an **attack** of measles" or "an attack of malaria" for one episode of the disease. 'Epidemic' involves many people, not one person; 'encounter' is too general, and 'indisposition' usually refers to minor illness.

questions.question: However, once you have had an attack of this dreadful disease, you develop an ....15.... which is almost complete and long lasting.
questions.explanation: After recovering from certain infections, the body develops **immunity**—resistance to future attacks. The adjectives "almost complete and long lasting" describe immunity well. 'Armour' is metaphorical and less precise; 'impurity' and 'ability' are wrong in context.

questions.question: Modern science has made available ....16.... to prevent many childhood diseases.
questions.explanation: While injections and tablets can both deliver medicine, the specific tools that *prevent* childhood diseases are **vaccines**. In fact, vaccines are usually administered by injection, but the question wants the exact technical term.

questions.question: Modern science has made available vaccines to prevent many childhood diseases and this is the only guarantee of ....17.... from these scourges.
questions.explanation: Vaccines do not cure a disease you already have; they provide **protection** against getting it. Option D reflects this preventive role. 'Freedom' is too general; 'discharge' is a legal/hospital term; 'cure' would apply to treatment after infection.

questions.question: More effective treatment of complications arising from these childhood diseases using penicillin and other ....18.... has also helped to reduce the ....19.... rate among children.
questions.explanation: Penicillin is a classic example of an **antibiotic**, a drug that kills bacteria. The phrase "penicillin and other antibiotics" is medically accurate and standard. 'Relievers' suggests painkillers; 'treatments' is a broader term than the example given; 'pills' are just a form of medicine.

questions.question: More effective treatment ... has also helped to reduce the ....19.... rate among children.
questions.explanation: The standard collocation in demography and public health is "**mortality rate**"—the rate at which people die. 'High rate' is incomplete, and 'killing rate' and 'dangerous rate' are unidiomatic.

questions.question: It is universally accepted that good ....20.... is the right of every human being and children.
questions.explanation: The phrase "good **health** is the right of every human being" is a common expression in discussions of human rights. 'Body' and 'sense' are concrete nouns that do not collocate with 'good' in this way; 'development' is an outcome of good health but not the basic right being emphasised.

questions.question: You do not have to die from these diseases which wiped out the whole ....21.... in the middle ages.
questions.explanation: Historically, epidemics are often described as wiping out whole **communities** (groups of people living together). While entire countries or states can be badly affected, the typical phrase in epidemiology and history is that communities or villages were wiped out.

questions.question: We have today ....22.... drugs which give protection against most childhood diseases.
questions.explanation: The key quality of these modern drugs is their **potency**—they are very strong and effective. 'Bitter' refers to taste, 'lovely' and 'marvellous' are emotional reactions, not scientific descriptions.

questions.question: When asked to state her side of the story, Bunmi started by beating about the bush. This means that Bunmi

options.text: approached the subject without coming to the point

questions.explanation: The idiom "beat about (around) the bush" means to avoid talking directly about the main thing, often by giving irrelevant details. So Bunmi talked *around* the issue rather than going straight to it. Option D captures that; A is the opposite, while B and C misinterpret the idiom literally or incorrectly.

questions.question: The amount he donated was small. He said it was his widow's mite. This means that

options.text: it was all he could honestly afford

questions.explanation: The expression "widow's mite" comes from a biblical story about a poor widow who gave a tiny amount of money but it was all she had. It now means a small but sincere contribution given from limited means. So the donor is saying the small sum was all he could genuinely afford. He is not necessarily miserly (B).

questions.question: The friendship between Segun and Shehu has turned sour. This means that Segun and Shehu are
questions.explanation: A relationship that "turns sour" becomes unpleasant or hostile. It may not literally mean they never speak again, but in exam terms it implies they are effectively no longer friends. Options B, C and D all suggest the friendship is intact or improving, which contradicts the idiom.

questions.question: The driver smelled a rat when the policemen asked him to stop. This means that the driver was
questions.explanation: "Smell a rat" means to feel that something is wrong or that someone is trying to deceive you. It is about **suspicion**, not recklessness or politeness. So the driver became suspicious of the policemen's motive.

questions.question: The students were advised to face their studies and let the sleeping dog lie. This means that the students should

options.text: leave matters as they are now
be as watchful as sleeping dogs

questions.explanation: The idiom "let sleeping dogs lie" means not to revive old disputes or problems; leave them alone. Here, students are told to focus on studies and not stir up any trouble or past issues. That matches option C. A and B may be good advice but do not interpret the idiom; D misreads it literally.

questions.question: From the way Ngozi behaves, it is obvious she is a greenhorn. This means that Ngozi is
questions.explanation: A "greenhorn" is someone new to a job or situation—an inexperienced person. The word has nothing to do with arrogance, caution, or civilisation.

questions.question: The economic situation is so bad that many wage earners are hardly able to make both ends meet. This means that

options.text: most people are extravagant with their income
people's earnings are not sufficient for their essential needs
most people engage in activities that bring them extra pay

questions.explanation: To "make both ends meet" means to have enough income to cover basic expenses. If people are hardly able to do this, their earnings are **insufficient** for their needs. So C is correct. A says the opposite; B blames extravagance, which the sentence does not mention; D is about extra income, not inability to cope.

questions.question: Since I found out his hypocritical nature, I have been keeping him at arm's length. This means that I
questions.explanation: To keep someone "at arm's length" means to keep them at a distance—avoid close contact or intimacy. Practically, that means not visiting or associating with the person closely any more. It does not necessarily involve reporting them to authorities or simply ignoring advice.

questions.question: I knew Okoronkwo's father very well and I must say that his son is a chip off the old block. This means that Okoronkwo

options.text: has chosen the same career as his father
is very much like his father
is an extremely different sort of person from his father
has taken up a different profession from his father's

questions.explanation: The idiom "a chip off the old block" means a child is very similar in character or behaviour to a parent. It does not refer specifically to career choice (A or D). C is the exact opposite of the idiom's meaning.

questions.question: The debating team was warned to make convincing points and not to play to the gallery. This means that the team should not
questions.explanation: "Play to the gallery" means to act in a showy way just to get applause or approval from the crowd rather than to present solid arguments. It refers to seeking cheap popularity (D). The other options mention different weaknesses not captured by the idiom.

questions.question: Anyone who thinks that he can succeed in life without working hard is living in a fool's paradise. This means that such a person

options.text: thinks hard work is merely a joke
is on the verge of insanity

questions.explanation: A "fool's paradise" is a state of illusory happiness or security—one believes things are fine when they are not. So such a person is living under an illusion (A). The statement does not claim he thinks others are fools or that he is literally insane.

questions.question: I am happy to inform you that your boys are conscientious.
questions.explanation: "Conscientious" means diligent, careful, and guided by a sense of duty. The opposite is "carefree"—not worrying about responsibilities or duties. 'Industrious' and 'careful' are near‑synonyms rather than opposites, and 'corrupt' refers to moral dishonesty, which is a different dimension.

questions.question: My father is a very prosperous businessman.
questions.explanation: A "prosperous" businessperson is successful and financially well‑off. The direct opposite is "unsuccessful". 'Unskilled' concerns ability, not results; 'unscrupulous' describes dishonesty, and 'ungrateful' is an attitude unrelated to prosperity.

questions.question: My hostess greeted her guest in a very relaxed manner.
questions.explanation: A "relaxed" manner is easy, informal, and not tense. The opposite interpersonal style is "stiff"—formal, rigid, perhaps uncomfortable. 'Energetic' is about activity level, 'athletic' about physical fitness, and 'perplexed' about mental confusion.

questions.question: Ayo takes his studies rather lightly.
questions.explanation: To take something "lightly" is not to give it the seriousness it deserves. The direct opposite is to take it **seriously**. 'Carefully' relates to thoroughness but not necessarily seriousness; 'humorously' and 'tediously' describe style, not attitude.

questions.question: The doctor was very gentle with his patients in the examining room.
questions.explanation: "Gentle" refers to mild treatment—kind and not rough. The strongest, most direct opposite here is "harsh", which implies severe or rough treatment. 'Rude' is about manners; 'unkind' is less precise; 'rough' is close but 'harsh' better captures the contrast in medical bedside manner.

questions.question: The President took exception to the ignoble role the young man played in the matter.
questions.explanation: "Ignoble" means base, shameful, or lacking in honour. Its direct opposite is "honourable". 'Dishonourable' is actually a near‑synonym, not an opposite. 'Embarrassing' and 'extraordinary' refer to emotional or unusual qualities, not moral worth.

questions.question: The man who had been seriously ill was convalescing at a seaside resort.
questions.explanation: To "convalesce" is to recover health gradually after illness; it is similar to "recuperating" (C) or "regaining health" (A). The opposite of recovery is worsening, that is, "deteriorating in health" (B). The question asks for the opposite in meaning, so B is correct.

questions.question: For millions of years, the world resources have remained boundless.
questions.explanation: "Boundless" literally means without bounds or limits. Its direct antonym is "limited". "Scarce" describes small quantity, which is a consequence of limits but is not the precise lexical opposite. 'Indomitable' (unable to be subdued) is unrelated.

questions.question: The difference between the experimental procedures was imperceptible to me.
questions.explanation: "Imperceptible" means so slight that it cannot be noticed. The opposite is "obvious"—easily seen or noticed. 'Significant' suggests importance, not visibility; 'negligible' is actually close in meaning to imperceptible, not opposite; 'obscure' also means hard to see or understand.

questions.question: His antipathy to religious ideas makes him unpopular.
questions.explanation: "Antipathy" is a strong feeling of dislike or aversion. The opposite attitude to ideas is open‑mindedness or **receptiveness** (willingness to accept). 'Hostility' is actually similar to antipathy. 'Remedy' and 'consciousness' do not express an attitude of like or dislike.

questions.question: He was ... by the trickster.
questions.explanation: A "trickster" is someone who cheats or deceives others. The verb that fits logically is "duped", meaning fooled or cheated. 'Assisted' and 'encouraged' are positive; 'enjoined' means commanded or urged, which does not necessarily involve deception.

questions.question: When the soldiers saw that resistance was ..., they stopped fighting.
questions.explanation: If resistance is "futile", it means it is useless and cannot achieve its aim. That gives the soldiers a clear reason to stop fighting. 'Inadequate' or 'inefficient' suggests weakness but might still allow some hope; 'successful' would be the opposite.

questions.question: You should read all the ... carefully before you decide where to go on holiday.
questions.explanation: Tourist information about holiday destinations is presented in **brochures**—colourful booklets advertising different places. A 'prospectus' usually describes a course of study; 'tickets' are bought after deciding; 'handouts' is a vague term for leaflets or notes.

questions.question: The Emir and conqueror of the enemy territories ... next week.
questions.explanation: Although there are two titles—"the Emir" and "conqueror of the enemy territories"—they refer to **one** person. Therefore the subject is singular and requires a singular verb: "arrives". Options B and D use plural "are"; C omits the auxiliary needed to express future arrangement in this style.

questions.question: We ought to have visited the Governor, ...?
questions.explanation: For tag questions, the auxiliary in the tag generally matches the verb in the statement. The verb here is the modal "ought to" in the perfect: "ought to have visited". The correct negative tag is therefore "oughtn't we?". "Shouldn't we" changes the modal, and the other options do not form proper tags.

questions.question: He didn't sense Obi's presence in the room, did he?...
questions.explanation: A negative statement with a positive tag—"He didn't sense..., did he?"—normally expects a negative confirmation. The logically consistent reply is "No, he didn't." (D). A would contradict the assertion; B is grammatically incomplete; C uses a double negative incorrectly.

questions.question: You can stay here ... as you are quiet.
questions.explanation: The fixed conditional structure is "as long as" meaning "provided that". So, "You can stay here **as long as** you are quiet." 'So long as' is possible in some contexts but the pattern here calls for 'as long as'. Options C and D are ungrammatical.

questions.question: The witness averred that she had seen Dosun at the scene of the crime.
questions.explanation: To "aver" is to assert or state positively and confidently. The closest synonym in the list is "affirmed"—to declare something to be true. 'Argued' suggests debate or reasoning, while 'confirmed' is usually used when supporting an existing claim rather than making the original statement.

questions.question: The high cost of living these days calls for a lot of frugality.
questions.explanation: "Frugality" means careful and sparing use of money or resources. "Economy"—in the sense of thrift—matches this meaning closely. "Prudence" is cautiousness in general, not specifically about spending; 'extravagance' and 'recklessness' are near‑opposites.

questions.question: Tunde's reaction underscores the points I was making.
questions.explanation: To "underscore" literally means to underline; figuratively it means to **emphasize** or give special importance to something. Hence C is correct. 'Justifies' means shows something is right; 'clarifies' means makes clearer; 'summarizes' means gives a brief account—related but distinct ideas.

questions.question: Everyone admired the manager's adroit handling of the crisis in the company.
questions.explanation: "Adroit" means clever, skilful, and resourceful, especially in handling difficult situations. The nearest synonym is "skilful" (B). 'Tactless' and 'clumsy' are almost opposites, and 'emphasised' is unrelated.

questions.question: The principal took exception to the ignoble role the teacher played in the matter.
questions.explanation: Here the italicised word is "ignoble" and the instruction for this set is to choose the **nearest in meaning**. Ignoble means base, mean, or lacking in honour. "Dishonourable" (D) matches this meaning. 'Embarrassing' focuses on shame for the observer, 'extraordinary' on unusualness, and 'honourable' is the opposite.

questions.question: KEY
questions.explanation: In *key*, the underlined vowel is the long /iː/ sound /kiː/. *Seat* /siːt/ has the same /iː/ vowel. *Sit* has the short /ɪ/; *bet* has /e/; *tread* has /e/ followed by /d/. Phonetic questions test sound, not spelling similarity.

questions.question: TAUGHT
questions.explanation: In *taught*, the underlined vowel sound is /ɔː/ (as in *tawt*). *Law* /lɔː/ has the same vowel. *Aunt* varies by accent but often /ɑː/; *count* has /aʊ/; *plateau* ends with /əʊ/ in many accents. Matching the long /ɔː/ sound is key.

questions.question: comfortable
questions.explanation: *Comfortable* is usually pronounced with three syllables: COMF‑ta‑ble or COM‑f't‑ble, and the main stress is on the **first** syllable: /ˈkʌmf(t)əbl/. Option A, **COMfortable**, marks that correctly. The other options shift stress to later syllables, which does not match normal English pronunciation.

questions.question: incapacitate
questions.explanation: *Incapacitate* has five syllables: in‑ca‑PA‑ci‑tate. The stress falls on the **third** syllable, giving /ˌɪnkəˈpæsɪteɪt/. Option B, **incaPAcitate**, reflects this pattern. A stresses the second syllable, and C and D stress the first and last syllables respectively, all of which are incorrect.

questions.question: encouragement
questions.explanation: *Encouragement* has four syllables: en‑COUR‑age‑ment. The main stress is on the **second** syllable: /ɪnˈkʌrɪdʒmənt/ (en‑COUR‑). Option B marks this correctly. The other options place stress incorrectly on the first, third, or fourth syllables.
